comment._content: Hmmmm....and exactly how does this zero gravity facility work?  Is it actually a vacuum chamber instead?

comment.author: 81256459@N00
comment._content: Didn't know that Glenn had a neutral buoyancy facility.  The only one I'm aware of was/is at Johnson Space Center.

comment.author: 44494372@N05
comment._content: Here's more on the NASA GRC Zero Gravity Facility: facilities.grc.nasa.gov/zerog/ (it's a drop tower) "The Zero-G facility provides researchers with a near weightless or microgravity environment for a duration of 5.18 seconds. Microgravity, which is the condition of relative near weightlessness, can only be achieved on Earth by putting an object in a state of free fall. NASA conducts microgravity experiments on earth using drops towers and aircraft flying parabolic trajectories. Allowing the experiment hardware to free fall a distance of 432 feet (132 m) creates the microgravity environment at the Zero-G facility."
